heatherinthesun: I needed to see this today. Thank you.
samm.withtwoms: Asking for a friend: can a 15y/o really consent to someone 6-7 years older than themself especially when being manipulation is involved? alexaralph: ❤️ All I did for the first three months of therapy after my rape was question myself. It’s so hard to stop, even now.
canvasmindd: Yup. Always ask if I'm sure to this day. Thank you for this post🙏
veghani: i feel this all. the. time.
wartofight: I truly feel what you wrote there. I also went through these thoughts over and over again. Sending you love.
meghoogendam: I've been doing the same thing lately, hastening and thinking about what happened that day. Questions such as ”did I really say no?” ”did I tell him to stop?” ”did it really happened?” but I did. Did you ever go to the police or a place where you could share what happened? And did it help? Lots of love,
illuminatrixx: Beautiful post. I really enjoyed reading it
evhughes44: ur so right that those questions are asked by demons "are you sure?" I always hear that in my head
linayogifreeman: Beautifully written, expressed, and shared. Thank you so much for your words💕
laurajendusa: Thank you. Thank you. Thank you for writing this reflection. Me too.
feelings_witch: Fuck. Yes. All of this, yes. The horrible thing about trauma is that it takes away our self-trust too. Thank you for putting words to this experience. 🖤
femfirewitch: Thank you thank you thank you 🖤
bigjoelleenergy: I relate to your words so much. Thank you. 🖤
_biancarosen_: @evyan.whitney So many survivors I talk to on the hotline tell me they aren’t sure what happened is actually sexual assault. After giving them the definition of sexual assault, I always validate the power of their intuition and the gut feeling that told them it was wrong. If it felt wrong, it was. I want you to know I believe you. Thank you for sharing feelings/doubts that so many of us have.
georleneflows: This year I’ve had a lot come up from my childhood that I don’t think I’ll ever be able to talk about.. but I find myself constantly asking myself did it really happen how I think it did or am I overreacting.. taking my power back and healing from such a traumatic experience at such a young age is honestly so hard.. especially when it’s kept inside from fear that no one will believe or they will judge you because of the experience.. I’m not sure why I’d be judged but maybe it’s cause I’m sitting here judging myself and trying to tell myself it didn’t happen when I know exactly what happened.. I guess I really just want to say Thankyou for this post! I needed to read this 💖💖
meganfrancis.d: I feel this.. unequivocally, always, vs my abuse. I am still battling it out in court over a year later, having to tell what happened over and over again to strangers, to the attorneys, have to see him and look him in the eye every few months in court. It’s debilitating to say the least, and as I move away from it I begin to question my story in this way. I start to invalidate as a means of defense of myself.
megancimino: Wow. Thank you so much for sharing your eloquent words. They are so relatable. I'm saddened to see how many people can relate, but comforted in knowing I'm not alone. Thank you, Ev'Yan for the work you do. You are such a blessing to this world💕
heybreu: Thank you so much for sharing this, and for once again helping me shed some light on my internal voice that is always telling me 'are you sure'? toranmcgill: I believe you. I see you. I am holding space and I THANK YOU for taking up space for creating space and for speaking into this space
layabilawnge: Thank you for putting in to words the feelings I never was able to understand. Thank you. I believe you and I believe all of us.
teresa.valiquette: This is shared so beautifully. So many women need to hear this, myself included. Thank you for being you. 🙏😭
literallylydia_: Thank you. This helped me so much. It’s invaluable

abbigalevirens: I needed this! But young me needed it even more. We need more discussions about (re)learning our past and how our original narratives are not necessarily more “true” than our later discoveries.

mrs.blair.martinez: I am fairly new to your page. Thank you, from the bottom of my heart, for your posts. You have already touched me in so many ways. Thank you. I hear you, I see you, and I am so grateful for your knowledge.
the.wild.sage: I have chills! Those same thoughts invade my mind, always taking me back making me unsure of my truth, even though I KNOW. I know what happened to me and I know it was not asked for and I know it was wrong. Thank you for putting words to what I sadly many of us feel. 🖤🖤🖤
talialune: Oh. This hit me in the gut. Me too. I STILL ask myself, am I sure??? 😢
evyan.whitney: biggest love to @jimanekia for her expertise & for holding space for all of us in that episode. because whew—I needed that. ✨💖
unspeakablymodern: Omg. Thank you. Thank you. My abuser asked me to call his new girlfriend and tell her I was over-reacting when I posted about it on my Twitter (without naming him). He asked me how to explain it to her in a way that wouldn’t break them up. He told me he couldn’t apologize to me in person because it would hurt her too much. I loved him and helped him through law school. It’s been 8 months and I still feel like a crazy person - like the bad guy. I feel ruined and unlovable. I feel like I deserved it for all the ways I wasn’t good enough for him - even when I know, factually, I was great. I wish I could give you a hug. Im so so sorry you are also haunted by these monsters.
petitobjeta: Trust the traces, the shadows, the echos- they are your truth. ❤️
banafshae: thank you so much for this 💞
meat.grindr: Thank you for sharing.💗 I doubted myself so much that I couldn't call it what it really was (rape) until a close friend pointed out that that's what it was. taberstockstill: It took me 4 years to say and believe the words “I was raped and it was absolutely not my fault.” I see you. And I believe you.
